The scenarios painted in the first chapter, Beyond Your Worst Nightmare, are enough to shake everyone's foundations. In it, scientists and experts such as Jodi Jacobson of the Worldwatch Institute and James Hansen of the NASA Goddard Space Institute project what life on Earth might be like in the year 2040. They speak of unbelievable conditions caused by our No. 1 problem global warming. Sea levels will rise to flood low-lying coastal regions. Droughts will occur in the breadbaskets of the world and famine will be a daily occurrence. As well, there will be an increase of epidemics and great waves of people roaming the planet in search of a safer place to live. top_1_text: ML COST $400,080 Several New Intercepting Sewers Proposed by Mr St George THE FLOODING OF CELLARS In Great Part Caused by Outside Municipalities-The City Surveyor had Reported This but no Action was Taken by the Council The City Surveyor has addressed the following important communication to the chairman and members of the Road committee on the flooding of cellars, and also on the necessity of constructing a new intercepting sewer on Sherbrooke and St James streets. It reads as follows: Gentlemen, I beg to attach you herewith a report of Mr Brittain, recommending the construction of a new intercepting sewer on Sherbrooke street from Beaudry street to Coteau Neiges road. The construction of this sewer has become necessary by the fact that the city is receiving so many claims for flooding through the overflowing of the Coteau Harron main sewer and the intercepting sewer during very heavy exceptional rain storms. In my opinion these claims should not be entertained for the following reasons: 1. The Coteau Harron main sewer was built in 1867 in a low swampy valley, when the street was not formed and consequently no houses could have existed then.

query: What political responsibility does the city attribute to Westmount municipality regarding the flooding issues associated with the intercepting sewer on St Catherine street, according to the passage?
top_1_text: The construction of this sewer has become necessary by the fact that the city is receiving so many claims for flooding through the overflowing of the Coteau Harron main sewer and the intercepting sewer during very heavy exceptional rain storms. In my opinion these claims should not be entertained for the following reasons: 1. The Coteau Harron main sewer was built in 1867 in a low swampy valley, when the street was not formed and consequently no houses could have existed then. The natural conclusion is that the houses must have been built since the sewer was constructed, and therefore, the city should not be held responsible. In regard to the intercepting sewer on St Catherine street, there is only one portion of it which is at present needed during heavy rainstorms, that is between St Lawrence and St George streets. These floodings take place only when there is an exceptionally heavy rainstorm, but these floodings would not have occurred if Westmount municipality, who had the permission of the city to drain their drainage into the intercepting sewer, had abided by the plan which they submitted to the city.

top_1_text: BERMUDA CYCLONE No Loss of Life Reported but Much Damage to Property Bermuda, September 13 A cyclone swept over this island last night. Houses were blown down and others were unroofed. The storm began with heavy rain after which there was a slight lull for a few hours, with the wind S.E., and the barometer steadily falling. The wind suddenly backed to east, blowing with cyclonic gusts. From eight p.m. to midnight it blew with hurricane force and was at its worst from 1 a.m. to 1:45 this morning. The wind blew down houses and unroofed others. Giant cedars were uprooted, ornamental and fruit trees were destroyed and wharves were washed into the sea. So far, no lives have been reported lost, but both ends of the island have yet to be heard from. The causeway was badly damaged. All communication was cut off from St. Georges and news from the western end of the island and the dockyard is not procurable at present. The telephone and telegraph poles and wires are down causing a total interruption of business. There has been considerable damage at the military camp.

By last night the storm had dumped 43 centimeters at Chicago's Midway Airport, 31 centimeters in Milwaukee and 20 centimeters on Detroit Metropolitan Airport in Romulus. Wind gusting to 65 kilometers per hour created blizzard conditions and northern Indiana's LaGrange County pulled its plows off the roads because snow was drifting 1.5 meters to 2 meters deep. The research paper pegs the price of Canada's 1994 jobless rate of 10.4 per cent at $29 billion to $77 billion in lost productivity and another $14 billion in health crime and other social costs. The figures indicate Canada with an unemployment rate stuck at around 10 per cent this year once again stands to lose tens of billions of dollars to joblessness. The Human Resources Department study takes a rare look beyond the direct productivity costs of unemployment to measure the toll on physical and mental health marriages and communities. "We have to take account of those costs when we are talking about unemployment," said study author Marcel. Bedard, a researcher with the federal department, reviewed existing research and discovered, if not a certain link, strong indications that unemployment can cause higher levels of illness, premature death and crime. Experts agree on the reasons: Malnutrition among the poor, resulting in chronic disease. Generally higher stress levels in low-income groups, associated with mental disorders, alcoholism, suicide, accidents, heart disease and other illnesses due to high blood pressure. The unemployed are not the only ones to suffer the consequences of these problems, says Bedard's study, completed in June.

MISSOURI, ST. LOUIS, Mo., February 12. Without warning from the weather bureau a veritable Kansas blizzard struck this city at 11 o'clock last night and continued up to 6 o'clock tonight. Rain, hail, sleet and snow alternately swept over the city before a high wind. At daylight the street railways had abandoned efforts to run cars till the tracks were cleared by snow plows. All the railway trains that were not abandoned entirely were late, the Alton express from Chicago being eight hours behind time. The snow is four inches deep, which is phenomenal for this latitude, as time passed the storm increased in severity and at 2 p.m. the wind had risen to a 30-mile gait, with the thermometer 8 degrees above zero and falling. The casualties are numerous, but none serious.

top_3_text: But the retreat, through the snow and cold of winter, was an utter tragedy. A campaign that began with 423,000 combatants dwindled to 50,000 by its end, an "army of ghosts." Cold temperatures, coupled with reductions in visibility by blowing snow - including the inability to distinguish between snowpacks and leaden skies - led hallucinating souls into the wintry unknown, never to be seen again. Makeshift bridges were constructed over rivers by engineers, in inclement conditions, to make safe passage. But sometimes they collapsed or were bombed, with hundreds drowning or freezing to death. We get a good picture of the harsh environment Napoleon's army underwent when Durschmied includes climatic minutiae: "Army braces, attached to lead buttons, were used to hold up uniform trousers. In the extreme cold, these buttons became brittle and disintegrated, and soon soldiers were walking with trousers around their ankles. Added to this was the torture of buttonless fly-flaps, where the wind whistled in, causing stomach cramps, diarrhea and death." The effects of climate on ailments have been studied for many decades.

Scott's Jan. 21 letter blaming the decline of Montreal on the lack of foresight of the anglophone community is partially correct. However, two major events probably played a much greater role in the decline. Firstly, the discovery of oil in Alberta in the mid-1940s started Montreal East on its catastrophic decline. Until then, with oil just over 200 miles away by pipeline, Montreal East was Canada's third-ranked manufacturing centre. Secondly, the seaway coming into existence in the early 1960s benefitted the rest of Canada but severely diminished Montreal's traditional importance as Canada's transportation hub. Obviously, the subsequent political developments did nothing to stop the economic rot.

The wind suddenly backed to east, blowing with cyclonic gusts. From eight p.m. to midnight it blew with hurricane force and was at its worst from 1 a.m. to 1:45 this morning. Damage from ice will be most costly GEOFF BAKER The Gazette A senior insurance official now says the ice storm that has ravaged southern Quebec this week will cost more to fix than any other winter weather disaster in Canadian history. "I think this is definitely the worst storm where insurance was involved in terms of winter storms," said Raymond Medza, general manager for the Quebec region of the Insurance Bureau of Canada. Medza said that from the initial reports he's been getting, the cost of storm damage should rise well into the tens of millions of dollars when his umbrella association, which counts about 140 insurers in Quebec, starts getting financial estimates from members next week. Costly winter storms are unusual, he said, since the biggest inconveniences are usually limited to traffic chaos and not physical damage.

The $100,000 the city of La Baie spent on rain-making machines to add last summer's deluge to its main tourist attraction, La Fabuleuse Histoire d'un Royaume, didn't go to waste. It's only one short year since a huge storm dumped 277 millimetres of rain on the Saguenay region in three days, unleashing torrents of water that caused more than $700 million in damage, but the events of July 19-21, 1996, have already become part of the local mythology.

The report by the Senate agriculture committee follows weeks of testimony by government officials, industry representatives and individual witnesses from communities in several provinces. The committee repeatedly heard how the effect of an announced case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, on an Alberta farm last May and the discovery of a case in the United States last December - which was also traced to Alberta - went well beyond the many farmers who bore the brunt of the economic fallout. "How has this affected our area?" Ed Fetting, an economic development officer in Lethbridge, Alta., said, before the committee in February. "Currently, there is not an industry in our community that has not been affected by this, outside of the public sector." "Lumberyards, truck sales, electricians, plumbers, bulk fuel sales, veterinarian services, even down to the accountants and lawyers, have all been affected," Fetting added.

The good news is that in spite of Hurricane Andrew, most of Florida is still in one piece. The storm was so isolated as it ripped across the southern part of the mainland that communities 100 kilometres north of Miami were untouched. In fact, the weather that day over most of the state north of the hurricane's path was not unlike any other day this summer - sunny and blistering hot. However, where the hurricane did hit, the devastation was and still is mind-boggling. A storm like this picks no favorites. It ripped apart ritzy estates in posh suburbs south of Miami with the same intensity that it flattened mobile-home parks, migrant-worker camps and slum housing in communities like Goulds, Florida City and Homestead. The heaviest rainstorm since the memorable cloudburst of 1874, when nearly two hundred people lost their lives in the Butcher and Sawmill run districts, passed over this city about 11 o'clock last night. The rain fell in torrents and in a few minutes the streets were converted into small rivers. Cellars were flooded in all parts of the city and the Fifth Avenue cable cars were stopped by the water getting to the Washington Street powerhouse. Landslides are reported on nearly all the railroads leading into the city. The lowlands along the Ohio River were flooded and numerous farms were washed out. The storm was accompanied by a remarkable electrical display. Several houses were struck by lightning on Mount Washington. Fred Hippley's glass bottle factory and a stable in which there were sixteen cows and two horses were destroyed. The storm lasted three hours and the rainfall was three inches. Despatches from surrounding towns in western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio and Virginia report great damage from the storm.

THE ANCIENT CAPITAL Interesting Items Gathered In and About Quebec (From our own correspondence) QUEBEC, November 9 A serious landslide or snow avalanche occurred recently at Montmorency Falls. The top of the cliff, which rises some 300 feet above sea level, was moved forward by the prolonged action of the rain and tumbled downward with terrible force, smashing the outer covering of the main water power pipe of the cotton mill and causing extensive damage to the property below. Some hundred feet away another avalanche took place, the stone smashing through the lower part of a house and moving a barn some feet away. Had the main pipe burst the damage would have been immense, as the pipe has a diameter of 6 feet and a perpendicular height of 300 feet. The heavy rains which fell during the greater part of last week produced considerable floods in the surrounding parishes. In many of those lying between Jacques Cartier and Quebec bridge were swept away and roads were under water.

top_2_text: James Bay may affect birds on a continental scale: Audubon report MONTPELIER, Vt. Hydro-electric development in northern Quebec seriously threatens huge concentrations of birds that depend on the region for food, says a Vermont researcher in the summer edition of American Birds, a National Audubon Society publication. Christopher Rimmer, an ornithologist with the Vermont Institute of Natural Science, reported this month that damming rivers in James Bay could wipe out crucial feeding habitat for migratory waterfowl and shore birds. "An unprecedented ecological experiment is taking shape in the sub-arctic wilderness of northern Quebec," the article begins, "an experiment without controls, whose consequences may affect bird populations on a continental, if not hemispheric, scale." Rimmer wrote that the James Bay area consisted of wide coastal marshes, tidal flats and numerous shallow bays all of which serve as highly productive food sources for birds. Snow geese, Canada geese, Brant, American black ducks, Harlequin ducks and other waterfowl, as well as various species of shore birds, rely on the habitats for plants, insects and mollusks particularly during migration.
top_3_text: "At market values, the value of this lost wood is in the hundreds of millions of dollars per year." In Ontario, sugar maple growth is lower in areas with acid deposition exceeding the "critical load," says the report. The critical load is the amount of acid that an area can withstand without damage. In Quebec, hardwood and coniferous stands in areas where critical loads were exceeded had a growth rate 30 per cent lower than in sites without the excessive deposits. The problem is that acid rain is removing essential plant nutrients like calcium from soils via leaching, Heather Morrison, editor of the Environment Canada assessment, said in an interview yesterday. Elements such as calcium and magnesium not only nourish trees but also act as buffers which neutralize acid pollution, she added. The study also notes that acid deposition is growing in western Canada, and emissions in the west are projected to exceed those in the east if current trends continue.

top_3_text: Another consequence of damming is the disruption of animal and insect life along rivers, which depend on soils, microorganisms and vegetation. In the Great Whale drainage basin, for example, the vegetation supporting soil is down in the valleys and at the higher elevations it is mostly bare rock. When such valleys are flooded, the displaced animals and insects are left with less and less or no arable soils and in many cases, most cannot survive. Also, beavers who build wintering huts downstream of dams are chased out of them by rising winter water levels, at a time when snow cover precludes the building of new ones, not to mention their lost food reserves. And they die. In the La Grande river system, mercury levels due to decomposing vegetation are still rising after some 13 years (the natives are advised not to eat the fish) but there are signs that the rate of increase is slowing down. But we have no records to help us predict how long it will likely rise, level off, or drop to acceptable levels. Aquatic and land animals all form part of the food chain on which we inevitably depend.

top_1_text: Birds in the wild: "Seeing wild flamingos today is much rarer than it was then; you can expect to see some that were bred in captivity but there's no shortage of exotic birds you can see in the wild." The roseate spoonbill, often mistaken for a flamingo, is one. The rosy-pink birds swing their distinctive spoon-shaped bills back and forth through the bottom mud of Florida Bay until they strike something that could be dinner. You can also see wood ibises, which are really storks, the only storks native to the United States. There are reddish egrets and rare great white herons and Florida has more bald eagles than any other state except Alaska. About 50 pairs of bald eagles nest along the coast in the Everglades. top_3_text: Yet Baskatong Reservoir might well become a prime walleye fishing destination again before the turn of the century, thanks to the Association des Pourvoyeurs du Baskatong. The restocking operation is unique in that it was actually carried out by the outfitters using government facilities and expertise, marking a new trend in resource management at a time when the government itself is withdrawing from such activities in response to budgetary restrictions. Primary funding for the project comes from the Baskatong outfitters' association itself; the provincial fish and game department provided equipment and expertise, and Hydro-Quebec, the utility company which caused the decline in walleye numbers to begin with, provided a paltry $10,000 to be split between '94 and '95 stocking operations. top_3_text: Few people but a small group of dedicated shotgunners have ever seen a live woodcock, and chances are few people but those who thrill at the sight of a dog on point and the towering flush of the bird through the autumn birch and aspen would know a woodcock by name even if it was staring them in the face. Since 1968, Quebec's population of these secretive birds has been in a decline. Not much of a decline-only about 1.8 per cent per year - but a decline nonetheless. And when you take the accumulated impact of about a quarter century of a barely noticeable decline, you end up with a total loss of 39 per cent of the population in relation to what existed in the late 1960s. If it continues, the population will have been halved in another decade. In large part, the decline can be blamed directly on habitat loss. top_3_text: Threat eases; threat of famine for 20 million ASSOCIATED PRESS JOHANNESBURG - The threat of famine has eased across much of southern Africa after the worst drought in a century. But hundreds of thousands of people still struggle every day to find food to stay alive. Rains, which started in some areas in November, have broken the drought in much of the region. Crops are growing in fields that had been baked dirt. Rivers and reservoirs that had dried up are now filling. While aid workers never expected a disaster like the famine in Somalia, the drought last year was a threat to 20 million people in the 10 countries of southern Africa. Famine still threatens war-torn Angola, where 2 million people face starvation after being driven from their homes and farms. "For most of the region, the emergency is over. A disaster has been averted for the 20 million people who were seriously at risk," said Mercedes Sayagues of the UN World Food Program in Zimbabwe. There are no reliable figures on how many people died from starvation or drought-related causes. But the drought's aftermath and other economic problems have left hundreds of thousands struggling to survive. Many rural families survive on pittances while waiting for the first crops.

top_1_text: MARK STEIN LOS ANGELES TIMES Logging has created forest islands that can decimate sensitive plant and animal species. LOS ANGELES - Careful analysis of satellite images indicates the Amazon rain forest is being deforested at a "considerably lower" rate than recently estimated, but the impact on biological diversity may be greater than feared, University of New Hampshire and NASA scientists report. That apparent paradox is due to the pattern of forest loss, the scientists reported yesterday in the journal Science. Forests in the Amazon region of Brazil are felled in irregular patches that create "islands" of trees too small to support plants and animals normally found there. Besides stripping trees from 15,000 square kilometers of forest annually, logging often fragments habitats and upsets the balance of predator and prey. It also exposes the edges of these forest islands to climate changes, foraging livestock, humans and other influences that can decimate sensitive plant and animal species. This "edge effect," which the scientists blame for most of the damage in the Amazon, also has been seen near clearcut logging operations in the Pacific Northwest.

Almost all the provinces have been affected in greater or less degree, Nova Scotia suffering most perhaps and Quebec least. top_3_text: I am of the opinion that the proof establishes that the plaintiff's wife was struck and injured by snow and ice which fell from the defendant's roof. Comes the question as to the defendant's liability. Defendant has proved that he did not live on the premises and that the whole of the property was in the occupation of tenants, most of whom had by their leases undertaken to keep the roof free from snow and ice. The tenant, however, immediately over Lalonde, where the ice came from had no written lease, and had not assumed any obligation as to the care of the roof beyond that imposed by law. The municipal bylaws impose upon tenants the obligation of keeping the roof free from snow. By-Law No. 47, sec. 20. This, however, does not change the general responsibility of either owners or tenants to neighbors or persons passing injured by the fall of the building on any part of it or of ice or snow from it. Its only effect could be to render such occupants liable to the penalty enacted for failure to conform to the by-law. This case, in my judgment, falls under the provisions of articles 1053 and 1055 C.C., and is not affected by article 1054.

Cold temperatures, coupled with reductions in visibility by blowing snow - including the inability to distinguish between snowpacks and leaden skies - led hallucinating souls into the wintry unknown, never to be seen again. Hydro-Quebec has never drawn up any sort of contingency plan for working closely with municipalities, even though 80 per cent of Quebecers are dependent on hydroelectric power for heating. Hydro-Quebec does not even have a computer simulation on how to respond to a major power failure like this one. Experts do not doubt that better advance planning and coordination would have lessened the difficulties of coping with the worst recorded ice storm to hit Quebec. While Quebec's civil-protection service moved quickly in the first days to set up shelters, the absence of coordinated emergency plans inevitably led to a slowdown in its ability to respond to citizens' needs. The mayor of Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu had to launch a public SOS for generators, beds and blankets for its overcrowded shelter. Taking the ice jam as inevitable at this point, the real object is to secure a free passage for the water under the ice, and this could probably be best achieved by dredging out a deep channel on the east side of St. Helen's Island, tapping the deep current that strikes from the bridge to Commissioners Wharf (or leading direct from the bay) and entering St. Mary's current at a convenient point below Isle Ronde. The worst cyclonic thunderstorm ever known in this section burst over the city and vicinity about noon and lasted nearly an hour, doing enormous damage and causing the loss of three lives so far as known. The morning was bright and clear, but toward noon rain began to fall and the wind to rise, and in half an hour a terrific cyclone was sweeping along. The city proper was not in the direct path of the wind, which rose to over eighty miles an hour, snapping trees of two and three feet diameter like twigs, crushing barns like eggshells and unroofing dozens of houses in Roshelesterville, Billings Bridge, and other places in the direct path of the storm. At Billings Bridge, St. Thomas' Roman Catholic Church, a wooden structure, was blown to pieces.

top_1_text: Environmental groups in Scandinavia have for years been trying to expedite the cleanup of the Baltic, but until recently they have had few counterparts in what was once the Eastern Bloc. Now the Baltic has emerged as one of the chief concerns of the old East Bloc's fledgling environmental organizations. Two multilateral coalitions have recently formed the Balto-Scandinavian Information Centre and the Clean Baltic Coalition. The former, started by the green parties of the region, aims at general environmental and political cooperation. The Clean Baltic Coalition, composed of representatives of groups throughout the area, will focus initially on channelling Western funds to environmental groups and projects in the East. This air of informal cooperation seems to be invigorating efforts at the governmental level. In September, just two weeks after the Clean Baltic Coalition was officially founded, the prime ministers of all seven Baltic countries met to discuss the state of their shared environment. Moreover, it appears that Western governments are finally beginning to allocate to the Baltic the substantial amounts of money that will be necessary to back up their commitments. Although no money has yet been specifically earmarked for the Baltic, Sweden, Denmark and Finland have offered a combined amount of more than $160 million for environmental aid to Eastern Europe.

top_1_text: No action soon on English health care CAMPBELL CLARK Gazette Quebec Bureau QUEBEC - The new access plans for English-language health services will not be approved until late August or early September, a spokesman for Health Minister Jean Rochon said yesterday. Rochon made a presentation on the plans to the provincial cabinet last Wednesday, Rochon's spokesman, Martin Caille said. The cabinet made no decision on the plans, and no cabinet meetings are scheduled until August. That marks another in a series of delays in the process of approving the new plans, which outline how healthcare institutions will provide service in English. Caille would not say what Rochon recommended to the cabinet, or whether he would recommend changes to the plans, which were drawn up by the province's 16 regional health boards and approved by a provincial advisory committee. The plans became controversial when some Parti Quebecois members complained they would require the hiring of too many bilingual employees at French health-care institutions, and that would conflict with the right to work in French. Rochon then agreed to allow the Office de la Langue Francaise to review the plans, sparking an angry reaction from some anglophone groups, who said they feared the government would try to reduce access to English-language services.

top_3_text: Tanned and relaxed, just back from a Florida vacation, Bouchard chose a meeting of members of his riding association for his first public sortie since the Christmas holidays. The meeting was among the last of a series of riding-level sessions to elect delegates and adopt resolutions on various issues to be presented at the party's convention in May. One of those issues is Quebec's ailing health-care system. In a morning workshop, and later in his speech to his members, Bouchard said Quebec still has one of the best and most generous health-care systems in the world, but there must be a public debate on its future. "With an aging population and expensive new technology, health-care costs are rising faster than the province's economy," he said. If it is to preserve the universality and the accessibility of health care, Quebec must do things differently, Bouchard said. For example, people who years ago used to go to their family doctor are now going to emergency rooms for care, he explained. "We have to improve the organization of services. I am convinced we can improve accessibility and waiting times if we intervene in a more immediate way." However, he rejected proposals to introduce private health care.

top_1_text: "I often say there's more violence on the weather channel than on regular news," he said. The often-dramatic images of floods, hurricanes, droughts or other extreme weather events - no matter where on the planet they occur - have led us to believe that there are more such extreme events than ever. The number of events has actually remained relatively constant, but we're more aware of them. And when weather causes damage these days, it comes with a heftier price tag and the accompanying larger headlines, in part because human beings insist on building things where they know, or ought to know, they shouldn't. It was rare, Phillips said, to have a $1-billion damage figure attached to a weather event in the United States before 1987. But since that date, there have been 31 events with damage in the billions, he said. That is not only a function of inflation; it's because humans have continued to install luxury hotels and condominiums along the vulnerable coasts of the Carolinas, Florida and other hurricane-prone seaboard states. Indeed, when it comes to so-called natural disasters, which get people talking about the weather to no end, "the fingerprints of human beings are all over those events," Phillips said.

The research paper pegs the price of Canada's 1994 jobless rate of 10.4 per cent at $29 billion to $77 billion in lost productivity and another $14 billion in health crime and other social costs. The figures indicate Canada with an unemployment rate stuck at around 10 per cent this year once again stands to lose tens of billions of dollars to joblessness. The Human Resources Department study takes a rare look beyond the direct productivity costs of unemployment to measure the toll on physical and mental health marriages and communities. "We have to take account of those costs when we are talking about unemployment," said study author Marcel. Bedard, a researcher with the federal department, reviewed existing research and discovered, if not a certain link, strong indications that unemployment can cause higher levels of illness, premature death and crime. Experts agree on the reasons: Malnutrition among the poor, resulting in chronic disease. Generally higher stress levels in low-income groups, associated with mental disorders, alcoholism, suicide, accidents, heart disease and other illnesses due to high blood pressure. The unemployed are not the only ones to suffer the consequences of these problems, says Bedard's study, completed in June.

You can blame your firefighter parents RON KOTULAK AND JON VAN CHICAGO TRIBUNE CHICAGO "Pick your parents wisely" is standard tongue-in-cheek advice doctors give when asked the best way to ensure a long, healthy life, because genetics is so important a factor. If it were possible to take that advice, babies might avoid picking firefighters as parents. In a study published in the February American Journal of Epidemiology, analysis of more than 22,000 children born with birth defects revealed that firefighters' children had a greater risk of being born with an abnormal opening between their left and right heart chambers than did the offspring of police officers. While, as social groups, police officers and firefighters are much alike, it appears that firefighters' work exposes them to more toxins, which in turn affects the genes they pass on to their children. TEHRAN The toll in the earthquake that jolted northern Iran early yesterday rose to at least 25,000 dead, with tens of thousands reported injured, and it could go much higher when rescuers reach remote areas. The Iranian ambassador to the United Nations, Kamal Kharrazi, said yesterday afternoon on Cable News Network that the latest word he has received from the Foreign Ministry in Tehran was that an earlier estimate of at least 10,000 dead was far too conservative. And he said that even the latest figures are likely to increase as rescuers reach remote areas. Iran needs medical equipment, blood, blankets and medicine, he said. "I understand that international organizations are trying their best to bring some of this equipment and medicine." The earlier estimate was contained in a statement by the Iranian cabinet, made public after an emergency evening session. The announcement carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency placed all government organizations on full alert, and ordered an air bridge set up between Tehran and the stricken areas to evacuate survivors. Landslides blocked rescuers on the ground, and bad weather hindered helicopters trying to fly in supplies and take out victims, the news agency reported.
